Doesnt this look like an experiential ride at some theme park?! The Tactical Boat Handling and Firing Simulator (TBHFS) is the result of a collaboration between HTXsg and the . It is developed to meet the rigorous training needs of tactical boat operations and allow our Police Coast Guard officers to practise high-risk manoeuvres and experience different potential scenarios before embarking on live training out at sea! Click the link in our bio to find out more!

We are harnessing technology to save the day! UAVs (unmanned aerial vehicles) can be flown BVLOS (Beyond Visual Line of Sight) to augment our Home Teams efforts to keep Singaporeans safe and secure! Kudos to our engineers of RAUS (Robotics, Automation, Unmanned Systems) who worked closely with our partners, SPF and SCDF to ensure we can address missions more effectively.Click the link in bio to learn more about how the use of BVLOS technology can enhance the Home Teams operational capabilities. Unprecedented times calls for the joining of hands across agencies, tapping on the strengths and expertise of our CBRNE team. All hands on deck for our scientists, to run tests on swab samples timely and efficiently to secure our borders against COVID19. In fact, their tireless work continues regardless of a pandemic as the effort involved in countering CBRNE threats and hazards happens round-the-clock! Find out more from the perspective of our young CBRNE scientist via the link in our bio. Repost The swab test operation at our air, land and sea checkpoints was a multi-agency effort. The CBRNE teams task was to run tests on the swab samples to detect and identify travellers who had COVID-19 quickly, so that they could receive treatment. This also helped to curb the spread of the virus in the community. Ms May Ong, Director, Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear and Explosives (CBRNE), ..OneHomeTeam SGUnited SGTogether HTScienceandTech HTXSG technology

Fresh. Fun. Freedom. These are the words that undergraduate Sim Cher Boon used to describe his internship with our Cybersecurity Centre of Expertise, and dare we say, what many interns would hope to experience too!From being one of two winners at the inaugural Cyber Investigators Challenge 2019 that was co-organised by the Singapore Cybersecurity Consortium and MHA (just before HTX was formed), to joining HTX as an intern, we are glad to know that we have played a part in boosting interest and skills in cybersecurity beyond his course of study at Singapore Management University! Despite spending the bulk of his internship working from home due to COVID-19 safety measures, he has had a fulfilling and meaningful experience.We wish Cher Boon all the best in his future endeavours, and we hope to see you back at HTX, in his words, to contribute to the nations safety and security from an engineering and innovation paradigm!HTXsg HTScienceandTech sgsmu cybersecurity internship

When technology and human factor science meet, we are able to cater to more purposeful applications and to optimise safety and performance for our frontliners! With our Human Factors and Simulation Centre of Expertise working closely with to co-develop the smart wearable and the upcoming performance lab at the Civil Defence Academy, we are confident of the exponential impact in training efficacy and in our frontline being better prepared for the demanding missions ahead of them. If you do not enjoy what you are doing, you will never be passionate about it.One of two winners at the HTX sponsored Cyber Investigators Challenge (CIC) in 2019, Lee Zhen Hao is currently an intern with the Cybersecurity Centre of Expertise in HTX. He gets to uncover loopholes to discover vulnerabilities within software and applications now. This is something he has always have keen interest in. He finds the process fun and intriguing as it always requires him to think out of the box. It is no wonder then that his eyes sparkle as he tells us all about his internship project!Since the Singapore Institute of Technology undergraduates return from his all-expenses-paid trip to the RSA Conference, has been busy exploring the domain of information security to keep abreast of advancements. We trust his 11-month internship with us will continue to offer him the opportunity to experience first-hand, the integral role HTX plays in addressing, in his words, threats [that] directly impact people's daily lives and national security. HTXsg HTScienceandTech SingaporeInstituteofTechnology cybersecurity internship

To mitigate the risk of community spread from imported COVID-19 cases as Singapore begins to ease border restrictions, there was a need for a solution that can help better sustain efforts in enforcing Stay-Home-Notice (SHN) compliance. In customising the wearable electronic monitoring device, it was important that its design solution meets compliance needs and offers an effective, easy to use and self-service solution for Persons serving Stay-Home-Notices (PSHNs). How does this device the result of collaboration between Immigration & Checkpoints Authority and HTXs Immigration & Checkpoints Project Management Centre (ICPMC) and Sense-making & Surveillance (S&S) Centre of Expertise (CoE) work?Find out more at go.gov.sg/ewristband (link in bio) HTXsg HTScienceandTech OneHomeTeam

Thank you Minister for visiting us. We appreciate your words of encouragement as we strive to be at the forefront of technologyto empower the Home Team in the frontline!HTXSG HTScienceandTech: Utilising technology for a stronger Home Team.Visited and saw the range of tech capabilities being developed to support Home Team operations.HTX is also contributing actively to the fight against COVID-19. Our HTX scientists are working hard to test samples collected at all the air, land and sea checkpoints. Their work will help to guard against the spread of the virus, by detecting imported cases.I thanked the HTX officers for working round the clock in the labs during this period, to help keep our people safe.Looking forward to more tech solutions from HTX.HTScienceandTech

Their work will help to guard against the spread of the virus, by detecting imported cases.I thanked the HTX officers for working round the clock in the labs during this period, to help keep our people safe.Looking forward to more tech solutions from HTX.HTScienceandTech

If youve seen our post (bit.ly/cicwinner2019 - link in bio) on the winner of CIC 2019, heres Zhen Hao () giving us an update and sharing with us his experience on attending the RSA Conference 2020 in San Francisco last weekOur future intern said he had an eye-opening and mind-blowing experience, gaining new perspectives on the current security challenges from the expert-led sessions and keynotes. He stated that it was like a step into the future with countless exhibitions and each of them showcasing cutting-edge technologies that are not on the market, and solutions that were previously thought impossible to create. Another highlight he mentioned was meeting some of the creators of RSA up-close at the conference!Zhen Hao was thrilled to broaden his horizons by attending the physical workshops and trying car hacking and radio frequency (RF) hacking. He successfully manipulated the electronic device in the car such as the speedometer, door locks, starting the car and even deploying the airbags. He thoroughly enjoyed the hands-on experience of compromising a system as such an attack was only theoretically taught in school.It appears that Zhen Haos all-expense-paid trip has been most rewarding for him. CIC 2020 is happening again on 13-14 July this year! For those interested to join, look out for more details of enrolment for participation in May 2020! Follow our Instagram for updates!cybersecuritychallengeRSAConferenceSingaporeInstituteofTechnology

When Zhen Hao () participated in the inaugural Cybersecurity Investigators' Challenge 2019, heneverimagined he'd emergeawinner and earn himselfcash prize anda paid trip to San Franciscoto attendthe RSA Conference 2020!Recalling his intriguing and fascinating experience duringthe competition, the undergraduate at the Singapore Institute of Technology () quipped thatahighlight for him was "experiencing various real-life scenarios like live information gathering of volatile data from a computer to collecting fingerprints from a suspected plastic cup".Zhen Hao also felt elated when he managed to successfully solder a simple circuit board in order to communicate with a router management interfacea unique experience that helped him take a step back and appreciate the most essential part of a computer - the electronics and system architecture".As he makes his way to the RSA Conferencewhich started on 24 Feb, heis looking forwardto "many cutting-edge security technologiesbeing revealed at the conference".Followour Instagramforthe nextupdateon RSA Conference from Zhen Hao!cybersecuritychallengeRSAConferenceSingaporeInstituteofTechnology(Photos: Singapore Cybersecurity Consortium, Zhen Hao)
